content: The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes the construction and operation of US flag cruise vessels in the country. It also amends the Act to facilitate coastwise transportation of passengers. The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes US flag cruise vessel construction and operation, facilitating coastwise passenger transportation by specifying ownership and vessel requirements. The Merchant Marine Act, 1920 specifies requirements for vessels over 5 net tons to be issued a certificate of documentation under chapter 121 of title 46, US Code, with a coastwise endorsement. An exception is made for cruise vessels under a demise charter lasting at least 18 months, allowing them to operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after the charter ends. The Merchant Marine Act, 1920 allows cruise vessels under a demise charter to operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after the charter ends, subject to approval by the Secretary and compliance with specified terms. An exception is made for vessels not documented under chapter 121 of title 46, US Code. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 provides an exception for cruise vessels to be reflagged if they meet certain criteria, including being between 5 and 15 years old when documented under chapter 121 of title 46, US Code. The owner or charterer must also have a contract for the construction of another cruise vessel in the United States. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows cruise vessels to be reflagged if they meet specific criteria, including being between 5 and 15 years old when documented under chapter 121 of title 46, US Code. Additionally, the owner or charterer must have a contract for the construction of another cruise vessel in the United States. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for the reflagging of cruise vessels meeting certain criteria. The Secretary of Transportation may extend the initial 18-month period for an additional 6 months for valid reasons. Owners or charterers of cruise vessels in coastwise trade are restricted from operating any vessel between certain parameters. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for the extension of the initial 18-month period for an additional 6 months for valid reasons. Owners or charterers of cruise vessels in coastwise trade are prohibited from operating any vessel between specific ports or the islands of Hawaii. Violators may face civil penalties or forfeiture of their vessel. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 imposes penalties for violating vessel operation regulations, including a $1,000 civil penalty per passenger and potential vessel seizure for knowing violations. Additionally, individuals involved in cruise vessel construction contracts may be disqualified from coastwise trade. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 imposes penalties for violating vessel operation regulations, including disqualification from coastwise trade for individuals involved in cruise vessel construction contracts if construction milestones are not met. Coastwise trade includes passenger transportation within the United States or via a foreign port, and a cruise vessel is defined as a vessel of at least 10,000 gross tons. The term 'coastwise trade' encompasses passenger transportation within the United States or through a foreign port. A 'cruise vessel' is a ship of at least 10,000 gross tons with accommodations for 200 passengers, excluding ferries. A 'related person' includes holding companies, subsidiaries, affiliates, officers, directors, or agents of an individual or entity. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to deem certain vessels compliant with specific regulations and to require the issuance of a certificate of inspection. Vessels meeting certain criteria are described in the amendment. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows vessels with a coastwise endorsement to engage in coastwise trade under specific authorization criteria outlined in the Act of June 19, 1886. SEC. 5 amends the Shipping Act, 1916 regarding citizenship for vessel operation in passenger transport. SEC. 6 amends Title XI of the Merchant Marine Act, 1936. SEC. 6 amends Title XI of the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 by updating language regarding passenger and cargo. SEC. 7 addresses permits for vessels entering units of the National Park System. The Secretary of the Interior may only permit vessels to operate in National Park System units based on priority: first, vessels documented in the US or holding rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act; second, foreign vessels already permitted to operate in the unit. The Secretary of the Interior prioritizes vessel permits in National Park System units based on documentation and rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Foreign-documented vessels may have their permits revoked if a US-documented vessel requests permission that cannot be granted due to limits. The Secretary of the Interior may not revoke or refuse to renew permission for a person holding rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act to operate a vessel in a National Park System unit. Any person with revoked or not renewed permission to provide visitor services in a National Park System unit has the right of first refusal for a new permit when conditions change. The right is limited to the number of permits affected.
